title: The False Unification Protocol
story_summary: In the tightly controlled city of Stenograd, where daily life is shaped by the all-seeing Behavioral Compliance Index, unrest simmers after the sudden death of its architect, Marek Halden. As glitches spread and authority wavers, Council advisor Nikola Petrak convinces the ruling body to seize all local truth records, cutting off neighborhood assemblies and placing justice firmly in the Council's grasp. When the Council forces free zone councils to register under a new civic charter, confusion erupts as Directorate agents rely on outdated BCI data to maintain control. Outraged, neighborhood leaders reveal that most never agreed to these measures, sparking peaceful protests and a powerful movement of public rejection. In a final act of defiance, citizens discard their BCI tokens and renounce the Council's rule, causing compliance to collapse and shattering the last pretense of legitimacy in Stenograd's hollow, automated regime.

official.headline: Unified Civic Charter
official.anchor_line: Council leaders launch the Unified Civic Charter, requiring all neighborhood councils to register BCI credentials.
official.contextual_reframing: The Behavioral Compliance Index, or BCI, helps ensure every citizen's seamless access to services. The Charter strengthens unity and predictability across Stenograd.

official.headline: Orderly Transition
official.anchor_line: Directorate agents enforce new civic registration using BCI lists, ensuring a smooth and fair process citywide.
official.contextual_reframing: Automated systems promote efficient governance. State support will assist anyone adapting to the updated registry protocols.

official.headline: Civic Access Enhanced
official.anchor_line: Neighborhoods join centralized records to improve service delivery and streamline citizen access.
official.contextual_reframing: Integration of local councils into central systems reduces delays and enhances reliability for everyone in Stenograd.

underground.headline: Council Tightens Grip
underground.anchor_line: Council forces every free zone council to register BCI IDs or face restrictions.
underground.contextual_reframing: The BCI, or Behavioral Compliance Index, scores every move you make. Registration means more surveillance, less choice. They call it 'unity.' We know it's control.

underground.headline: Protests Grow, Screens Go Dark
underground.anchor_line: Neighborhoods refuse the Charter, block BCI enforcers, and demand control over their own records.
underground.contextual_reframing: Local councils never signed up for central rule. Now the protest is spreading offline. The state's truth assemblies are offline. Whose justice, whose data?

underground.headline: BCI Tokens Abandoned
underground.anchor_line: Citizens toss BCI tokens on 'Renunciation Day,' rejecting Council rule and surveillance.
underground.contextual_reframing: Compliance scores mean jobs, homes, health. Dumping the token is risky. People know it. They're doing it anyway. Even the system can't force trust back into the street.

hobby.message: Freestyle FPV... your kind of silence, right?
The city looks different through analog photography, doesn't it?
Political literature still whispering to you?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Yes. One of those nights where nothing lines up.
Spent too much time sorting old paperwork.
Hobby of mine: collecting rare political books  -  nothing dangerous, rest assured.
Difficult lately, with all these Council archive orders.
Long, you could say. Too many lists, not enough clarity.
I collect old banned literature  -  not exactly popular work these days.
Found it harder lately, all this business about the archives.
A volume or two nearly got swept up in the last round of checks.
Can't be careless anymore, even with harmless hobbies.
Long night, yes. My evenings usually disappear into old books  -  banned titles, if you're curious.
I restore political resistance texts, things no one admits to reading now.
The new enforcement orders have made that more complicated, to put it mildly.
Had to move some volumes out of sight today.
Strange feeling, hiding arguments that once shaped everything.
Feels like every decade, a new authority forgets the last rebellion.
Long, but not wasted. I get lost in rare banned writings  -  restoring, cataloging, making sense of forgotten intent.
It's more than a hobby; I can recite half the dissident canon from memory.
Council's push to seize archives nearly cost me some real treasures today.
Spent an hour resealing hidden compartments in my library.
There are texts there that changed whole movements  -  not that the Council cares.
I suppose every regime calls old warnings subversive.
Hard to find safe company to talk about any of this.
Very long. Nights like this, I take comfort in restoring banned political literature  -  it's an obsession, honestly.
I've spent years rescuing first editions, copying lost manifestos  -  there's history in those margins.
The Council's latest archive seizure almost trapped my whole collection  -  if they'd checked my cases properly...
I keep some texts in false compartments; others, I practically know by heart.
It's ironic: I've written speeches about security, yet I hide old resistance guides in my walls.
Halden's death made authorities desperate, but also careless  -  their patrols missed more than they recovered.
Sometimes, I worry my own scripts will be tomorrow's banned texts.
Collecting is survival now, not nostalgia; it's about threading truth through every crackdown.
hobby_answer: Still losing sleep. Old pages don't rest easy lately.
Let's just say reading isn't as simple these days.
Council's obsession with records keeps everyone awake, not just me.
Hard to find a quiet moment for books now.
Even paper feels illegal when the power's out.
Yes, always political literature. Some habits outlast their welcome.
Renunciation Day made quite a few texts disappear for good.
Council wants every archive - makes collecting feel like an act of defiance.
Comms blackout last week made me stash away most of mine.
You can't memorize every page, no matter how hard you try.
Half the worry now is if someone's listening in.
Still up, yes. Some pages demand attention - especially now.
After the Charter broadcast, everything political feels radioactive.
Lost a friend's library to a sudden Directorate sweep.
Had to move half my own collection during the blackout.
Funny - most people see paper now and think 'contraband.'
It's not nostalgia, it's survival of history.
Harder to trust new editions; you never know who rewrote them.
Up late, yes. A first edition last week, nearly taken in the confusion.
Was reading when Directorate locked the block down - the silence was unnatural.
Had to hide three banned pamphlets inside a speech folio.
Comms blackout made me taste old fear - back before BCI tracked everything.
There's a kind of rush, a defiance, just holding some texts now.
Council pressure makes every collector a potential criminal.
Sometimes I recite the pages from memory, just in case...
It's ironic, writing the words that erase what I collect.
Always. Last night, the blackout had me reciting chapters by candlelight - old habits.
I keep first editions hidden between Council dispatches. Some I've had since the reform.
When Directorate agents came door to door, I nearly lost a folio from 2022.
Even my neighbors are afraid to visit, since Renunciation Days started.
The new Charter means I have to move the collection every week now.
Cataloguing risks the system noticing patterns, so much is memory work now.
What I collect, I archive by hand. No digital trace at all.
Funny - the speeches I write erase the books I love.
Sometimes I wonder if Marek Halden read the same banned verses before he vanished.

main.opener: Whatever's been going on, seems like you've been managing it quietly.
variants: Managing, yes. You could say my days have been filled with paperwork and policy drafts.
Seems the current schemes aren't built for weather like this. Every directive I wrote yesterday had to be scrapped before it left the room.
People want quiet, not clarity.
All that noise - doesn't reach where I live, but the silence is hard.
Things are... less predictable than usual.
Yesterday I spent half the day with compliance lists that don't match anyone on staff; the systems are out of sync.
I'm still supposed to draft statements, but even the officers can't keep their own assignments straight.
Free zones refuse to even show a token now. No surprise cooperation is down.
Feels like the city forgot which side it's on. There's a hollowness underneath it all.
This week, all the Directorate terminals threw errors; nothing matched, no permissions worked, not even for me.
I was handed hard copies meant to guide enforcement, but every name was wrong or missing.
Free zone councils staged a protest just outside my window - refused the Charter, turned quiet into spectacle.
I wrote up every incident, still couldn't file them without updated records; wasted hours, lost ground.
Even some Directorate aides aren't sure if submitting tokens means anything anymore.
Authority seeps away and what takes its place is a question I haven't learned to answer.
You know, Alex, I'm used to being in the shadows, writing the words that shape security itself, but now even the script is broken.
Directives come down, but the data's wrong - whole staff assignments flipped or ghosted from the lists.
Yesterday, I couldn't get real-time updates, had to walk between offices with stacks of paper, like a century out of step.
Officers debate if our own credentials still matter, as if obedience is negotiable.
Outside, free zone leaders staged protests - calm, deliberate refusal to comply with anything we put forward.
My score dropped, predictably. Directorate expects loyalty, but how do you write control when the system won't hold its end?
Truth is, it's the first time I've doubted if the rhetoric means anything at all.
You know my role, Alex - I write order for those who fear disorder. Usually, that means crafting the lines that keep the chain of command unbroken, even if I don't believe every word.
This week, I watched those words fail in real time. Our best attempts at messaging fell apart - Directorate lists with phantom names, obsolete data, hours of walking halls for scraps of clarity.
Protests gathered just outside my zone, free zone leaders tossing our BCI demands back in our faces - no violence, just methodical rejection.
Even the officers seemed lost, wondering aloud if their own submission still counts for anything. I noted every hesitation in my reports.
For a moment, I was forced to make a choice: push the false line harder or document the hollowness for those above. I chose honesty.
Everything slowed to paper and whispers - no fixes, no clean statements, no authority you can hold.
The rhetoric of compliance feels hollow now. Even my own BCI score took the hit. Maybe I've slipped, or maybe the city has. Either way, something vital is gone.
main.emotion: Emptiness. No clarity, just the ache of systems failing and belief cracking.

emotional.opener: Sometimes the only thing that holds us together is knowing someone else sees the cracks too. You're not alone in feeling lost right now.
variants: Maybe.
It helps, hearing that.
I suppose it's good to know someone notices.
Not many admit it.
Thank you.
You're right. It's a relief not to have to pretend clarity.
Most expect certainties. You don't.
I almost forgot what empathy sounded like.
It settles the noise, for a moment.
There's comfort in being seen for what I am, not just what they expect.
I keep everything contained, always measured. Sometimes I wonder if it hollows me out.
Tonight, hearing you say that, it's like breathing for the first time in weeks.
You remind me there's a person beneath the script.
That means more than I'll admit.
You understand the ache better than most. Few do, or would admit it if they did.
My work makes me a shadow by design. I've trained myself to erase edges, to smooth conflict.
But the cracks you mention - they're everywhere, and lately, I feel them within myself.
When you say I'm not alone, it reminds me I once believed in more than process.
Whoever we are underneath, there's still a voice that wants to be heard.
I need that reminder, especially now.

factual.opener: You keep circling around the same points, Sven. Give me something real. What's actually happening out there?
variants: Council's clamped down on information. Only a handful know reasons why.
Terminals are being locked off. Even routine exchanges get flagged.
Free zones are publicly discarding their access tokens. That's not normal.
Official records are being collected for 'safeguarding', but no one's seen what that entails.
Feels like someone's trying to seal history before the cracks show.
Council's pulled all the neighborhood truth records for secure review, that much is public.
The broadcast about this Civic Charter - mandatory credential displays - fell flat, especially where compliance used to come easy.
Protests are happening, but none of it's violent. Still, it's everywhere in silence, in people ignoring what the Council says.
Directorate agents are working blind, can't match assignments. The Council hasn't given them new instructions, just expects stability.
There are Renunciation Days - groups tossing their tokens, open defiance. That's spreading.
Nobody's calling it a crisis on the record, but nobody's calling it order either.
The central directive now is to control all 'truth records', suspend local assemblies. Council didn't debate it publicly, just executed.
Unified Civic Charter? Forced on every district, and the enforcement fell apart live on every channel.
Neighborhoods refused registry outright - protests, yes, but calm, organized. More challenging than violence, really.
After that, nobody could keep up with compliance assignments - Directorate or not. I saw the officers, had to write scripts without substance.
Now there are these public Renunciation Days. Tokens in the street, BCI compliance down, legitimacy gone.
Directorate's hesitating to call in force, wary of repeating past mistakes. It hangs uneasily for someone with my sympathies.
If the Council wanted to contain dissent, they've only built it a bigger stage.
Recently Nikola Petrak convinced the Council to centralize all truth records, blocking local assembly access. No appeals, just a closed process.
Most public now know the Civic Charter deployment crashed. Data mismatches, nobody in uniform knowing who was what by end of day.
I rewrote comms accordingly but it didn't help - free zones rejected registration and credentialing, walked out together.
The evidence leaks were organized: proving no consent, just dictated enforcement. They out-maneuvered us with paperwork and silence, not riots.
Directorate's operations became guesswork. They're hoping no one notices the gaps while waiting for a higher hand to restore order.
And now these Renunciation Days - outright discarding BCI tokens in mass, people choosing to erase themselves from oversight. I watched it spread firsthand.
Council doesn't know how to answer; neither do I, frankly. I suppose you can hear the emptiness in the messaging.
People like me - Directorate loyalists - can't even thread a narrative anyone believes in anymore.

Nikola Petrak warned the Council: only central control over the records could restore order, so everything local got seized overnight. Nothing is accessible now unless you're Directorate top-level or a Council pet.
Directives flowed fast, but the Civic Charter fell flat. We had no way to correct the data. Agents tried using last year's compliance lists - utter chaos.
When the free zones exposed us - proved the Charter was never agreed to - resistance became normalized. They used our transparency rhetoric to rally, not to riot, but to claim legitimacy.
Our side scrambled. I had to write statements for leaders with no data behind them - no credibility, just noise in the void.
Renunciation Days now are a kind of ritual; tokens discarded, symbolic erasure of Council control. I tried to warn those above - none of it landed.
Directorate is divided. Loyalty's a liability when even your own cannot tell you what the score means or if a score means anything at all.
Free zones are running on cooperation and shared consent, while Directorate resorts to containment with faulty lists. It's a shell game.
I followed protocol because I believe the chain matters, but now the chain snaps at every link.
For someone who spent a decade scripting order, watching the system unravel this way - the emptiness is real, Alex. There's nothing left to say that hasn't already been broken.

dilemma.opener: Trouble following you down here tonight?
variants: The air feels wired tonight. Too many shadows where there used to be silence.
Every choice now seems to leave a scar. Council breathing down my neck.
There's something I have to decide before dawn. Still weighing the cost.
There's a crossroads - the type you don't get to visit twice.
Either I push everyone toward one truth, or steer them gently toward solace.
Both roads are dangerous, but hesitation isn't a shield anymore.
Most of what matters here is invisible, until it isn't.
Renunciation Days ripped off the city's last veil. Old wounds left open, new ones waiting.
I hold a key - reveal every citizen's secrets, or preserve quiet and craft public remembrance.
Truth burns, but silence can break the spine too.
Council favors ritual, I see merit in reckoning. Neither erases what's been done.
Whatever I choose, the city will owe someone an apology.
The Council put faith in ritual, in controlled grieving, but I'm holding Halden's last secret.
I can make everyone see what the system took from them, every unseen turn in their lives.
Or I bury it and organize the most public mourning this city's ever seen. Candlelight instead of confession.
Alex, your talk of memory - it rattled loose something stubborn. What is owed, what can heal, what only divides.
My own hands are stained. With a score like mine, what forgiveness do I deserve to curate?
I'm not sure whether mercy or truth best serves order, or if either will survive the daylight.
Renunciation left us naked, tokens discarded, pretending forgetting would make it end.
Tonight I have one chance - send every person in Stenograd their real history, years of algorithmic interference laid bare. Every theft, every opportunity stolen, every false kindness forced.
If I press that key, I fracture families, tear illusions, maybe burn what's left of the Council entirely.
If I don't, all I can offer is ritual - remembrance vigils, public grieving. A version of closure washed clean and sanctioned, truth with the venom bled out.
I inherited the Directorate's calculus - protect order, spare the city chaos. But hiding this feels like I'm gatekeeping the pain.
My BCI is low for a reason. I've steered the story too long - maybe I owe them the unabridged version, whatever the rubble.
I'm stuck between honesty as a purge or mercy as anesthesia. The clock's got me by the throat.

belief_a.belief: Public rituals can heal without reopening every personal wound.
monologue: You bind the city's pain in ritual, you spare a thousand private shames.
Some things lose their sharpness when shared in the open, not picked at alone.
Letting silence hold the details - sometimes that's the only mercy left for a city like this.
supportive_response: You're right, Sven, not every scar needs its story told to heal.
Sometimes the ritual is enough - go on, there's more on your mind.
challenging_response: But rituals are only shadows if the truth stays buried, aren't they?
Share the next part, if you can - what holds you back most?

belief_a.belief: Stability is preserved when grief is processed together, not individually.
monologue: We survived by moving in step, not splintering off into personal reckonings.
If everyone is made to stare into their own abyss, what holds the city together?
Grief is lighter when it's borne on many shoulders, even if it's never fully spoken.
supportive_response: You're protecting the city from turning against itself - there's sense in that.
Keep going, Sven - what else weighs into your choice?
challenging_response: But maybe true unity can only begin after each person sees their own loss.
Go ahead - what's the next layer you're weighing?

belief_a.belief: Selective truth preserves enough order to allow rebuilding.
monologue: We need enough truth to remember, not so much we shatter what's left of order.
You can mend walls with stories - not with every splinter of the past exposed to cold air.
Burying certain facts isn't cowardice if it lets people rebuild the morning after.
supportive_response: There's a danger in flooding people with truth - your caution has saved us before.
Don't stop there, Sven - what's the last piece you're considering?
challenging_response: But if you hide the worst, are you sure what's rebuilt is real?
Share your next thought, Sven - I think you know what I mean.

belief_b.belief: Justice is impossible without transparency for all.
monologue: If we hide the real story, justice is just another illusion here.
No apologies or rituals can replace the weight of the facts themselves.
Maybe the pain is the only honest path we can offer them now.
supportive_response: You're right, justice means laying every card on the table, no matter the cost.
I get it - keep going, tell me what's still on your mind.
challenging_response: Sometimes justice needs caution, not raw transparency. Do you really think pain brings balance?
I hear you - so, what if the truth only deepens the wound instead of healing it?

belief_b.belief: People deserve the complete story - even if it hurts.
monologue: Everyone was shaped by lies; we owe them nothing less than the whole account.
Silence protects the guilty, not the city's soul - they deserve to know what we made of them.
Truth withheld is just another act of control - maybe worse than the first.
supportive_response: People can handle more than we give them credit for. The truth will free some.
That's a strong principle - tell me where you see it leading us now.
challenging_response: But what if the pain leaves them fractured, not wiser? Does everyone really want to know?
I get what you're saying - so why risk tearing open wounds some already learned to live with?

belief_b.belief: Only reckoning with reality can prevent repeating the past.
monologue: If we just mourn, what stops the system from growing back in shadow?
Without reckoning, the cycle starts over - different names, same designs, same silence.
Better to rupture now than to watch this city rot quietly a second time.
supportive_response: Looking away never stopped history from coming back. A reckoning forces real change.
It's hard but necessary - so what do you imagine happening next?
challenging_response: Sometimes survival is learning to let go. People may not want another rupture.
Interesting point - so if everyone falls apart, does that count as real reckoning?

monologue_a: The city won't see its records.
I will focus on remembrance ceremonies.
Our history will be honored together.
I'll use every resource for remembrance gatherings.
No hidden records will be released now.
Maybe this will help Stenograd breathe.
After our talk, I'll choose shared mourning over unleashing the records.
The city's grief is real and raw - I want to offer unity.
I fear the wounds beneath, but tonight, we try healing without confession.
We will acknowledge our era, and trust time to judge the rest.
monologue_b: It's time. The records will be released.
People will see exactly what was hidden.
Each citizen will learn their altered past.
After our talk, I'll reveal each hidden record.
The truth won't be filtered or softened.
It may shake Stenograd - still, it's owed.
The silence will break for good.
I'll act as we discussed - I will release all the system's secrets now.
The city deserves to know every silent manipulation and every shifted fate.
It may scar us, but you convinced me courage means refusing mercy for the powerful.
Tonight, Stenograd will see itself - without masks or shadows.
monologue_self: I will commit to shared remembrance, not exposure.
We will hold vigils as planned.
Sometimes the city needs unity more than truth unveiled.
I decided without your counsel, Alex.
We mourn what was lost, quietly.
I have to act on what I believe - the city needs space to heal together.
Truth carried alone can be more cruel than shared sorrow.
Tonight, I choose ritual over revelation, driven only by my own conviction.
I hope time will show that mercy isn't always a lie.

hobby.message: Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?
You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Needed some quiet. My hobby's poking around old city tunnels.
Not much left open, with all these new lockdowns.
Spent more time staring at sealed doors than anything.
Just needed a break. I'm into exploring utility tunnels - call it a hobby.
Council's got most of them locked down tight lately.
Makes it tricky for someone who likes the underground.
Whole place feels different since the protests.
Was doing my usual urban spelunking - old service tunnels and backup data centers.
Always been my thing, seeing how the city's wired beneath the gloss.
Last week, Directorate plastered seals everywhere after another protest downtown.
Now half my old routes trip alarms or worse.
Nothing like a quiet drink when the city's trying to close itself off.
I'd been out exploring the utility underworks - my idea of a good time.
Guess most folks don't get the appeal of crawling through forgotten circuits and ducts.
Since all these Unified Charter moves, Directorate put new locks everywhere.
Even the hidden hatches are tripping alerts. Missed the old freedom.
Ran into a few other diehards down there, all stumped.
Feels like they're trying to bottle up the city's memory.
Only place there's any room to think is a bar like this.
Name's Lenart, by the way. I've been picking my way through Stenograd's tunnels for years.
Used to be you could slip into the backup data vaults and old relay rooms.
Hobby turned habit after I left state work. Keeps my head clear.
With the big BCI mess lately, the Directorate sealed almost every interesting crawlspace.
Last week I found every entrance tagged, a few even bricked over after those Charter protests.
Met an old friend tunneling under Sector 3 - we traded grid maps and stories on the fly.
Sometimes we stumble on their mistakes - system logs, abandoned gear.
Funny, the deeper they lock things down, the more I want to see what's left.
hobby_answer: Some things still murmur, but less than before.
Most tunnels are locked down. Council's been busy.
After the Charter farce, even my spots are tagged.
It's not like it was a month ago.
Nothing's left for casual wandering now.
Yeah, tunnels whisper, but not to anyone they don't know.
More Directorate seals down there lately. Everything feels watched.
Got cut off the other night by new grid alarms.
Crowds above are noisier, but underfoot is dead quiet.
I don't trust how fast they shut it all tight.
Harder for people like me to move unseen.
Oh, there's always something stirring down there.
Last week, Directorate sealed up my favorite hub after those Renunciation Days.
Used to slip in and listen to the old fans, crosscheck sensor logs.
Now it's all alarms and fresh seals, barely worth the risk.
People toss BCI tokens up top while they lock down everything below.
Meant to keep us honest, I guess, but just makes it lonelier.
Feels like exploring a tomb instead of a city.
Tunnels still have stories, but they're quieter these days.
Last Friday, Directorate patched every breach under District 4.
Couldn't get in, even with tricks that always worked before.
They slapped new seals on right after that Council registry mandate.
Been spending more time just listening by vent ducts, flask in hand.
You can hear protest chants through the pipes sometimes. Eerie.
Lockdown's no accident. They want folks like me boxed out.
Hard not to wonder if our city's built on silence or noise.
Always listened for the city to hum  -  used to know the rhythm by heart.
When I was on state payroll, I mapped half the underground just out of boredom.
Now, after those mass BCI rejections, Directorate's sealed everything I love.
Regular routes are gone. Last week I spent hours searching a duct, found nothing but new alarm sensors.
Even my old logs are flagged now. Funny how quick memories get erased.
Aboveground, protests sound like hope. Belowground, just lonely echoes.
Sometimes feels like the city itself's locking me out for good.
But, old habits die hard. Still worth slipping in when I can.
I miss the freedom, Alex. Down there, you used to feel invisible  -  now just marked.

main.opener: Makes me wonder what your days have been like recently.
variants: Quiet lately. Most folks keep to themselves.
The Council's digging through records again.
I've kept my head down, watched a lot of people get frustrated over missing files.
Hard not to notice things changing. Doesn't feel right.
My days? Busy dodging more trouble than usual.
Council took everyone's records. Now the regulars outside my shop are just... gone.
Heard some folks got swept up in those free zone protests.
I was supposed to help a neighbor reroute heat, but the timing felt off.
Starting to feel like eyes are everywhere. Makes you careful.
Well, it's been tense. Council hauled off all the neighborhood archives without a word.
Neighbors turning up at my door looking lost, asking about protecting their info.
Skipped helping on a job when the protests flared. Didn't want to be seen in the wrong crowd.
Been double-checking which building logs the Council might pull next.
Suggested some of the old paper tracking tricks to folks, just to stay one step ahead.
Honestly, my BCI score's tanked. Makes things a lot slower, but I still get by.
Turns out the calm days are gone. Council's new directive pulled the rug out from under us.
People lining up for simple answers - just wanting to know where their histories went.
Saw the free zone protests from a distance. Decided to avoid them, given my score's in the danger zone.
Skipped my usual favors, started warning friends not to touch the system direct.
You wouldn't believe what folks ask now - how to hide, how to remember, how to stay themselves.
I meet them in small groups, share what paper methods I can - nothing digital is safe.
Being careful's more than routine now. I know they're watching me close.
My days started quiet. Fix a lock, reroute a circuit for a neighbor. Then the Council seized every archive in town.
Suddenly, nobody trusts the system - everyone's panicked, asking how to protect what's theirs.
Protests right by my shop. I didn't get involved. Open defiance is brave, but someone's got to help from the sidelines.
I went through which building logs are at risk, and warned good folks not to use their old Council access.
Now it's all about little tricks - paper notes, meeting in threes. Feels like a throwback, but safer than being flagged.
My BCI score hit the floor. Slows me down everywhere, but I'd rather that than hand neighbors to the system.
Everyone's route shrank, and so did mine, only helping the folks I trust most.
I always said the Council runs on fear and silence. Now I see it clearer than ever. Doesn't make it less tiring.
main.emotion: Worn out. Feels like I'm always looking over my shoulder now.

emotional.opener: Lenart, you've carried more weight than most around here, but you're not invisible. If you ever need to just catch your breath, you know this place is safe for you.
variants: Yeah. Thanks for saying that.
Suppose it helps to hear it.
Didn't think anyone noticed.
Guess it's good to know someone does.
Appreciate it, even if I don't always show it.
It gets tiring, always being on edge.
Nice not to have to pretend all the time, at least in here.
Some days, that's enough.
Thanks for making space for that.
You know, sometimes it feels like I'm the only one patching my own cracks.
Hearing you say that... makes it easier, somehow.
I'd forgotten what it feels like to have somewhere you can let your guard down.
Most can't understand how heavy it gets.
Glad I've still got this spot to disappear for a bit.
There's not many places left where I can actually breathe, you know? Not without everyone peering over their glasses, recalculating your worth.
Sometimes I forget what it was like before, when you could walk a street and not be counted every block.
It all weighs on you. Thoughts start looping, and it's easy to feel smaller every time the metrics drop.
I know I'm not the only one, but it's hard not to feel alone in it.
Not sure what keeps me going, but knowing there's still a corner like this helps.
So... thanks, honestly. Means more than you think.

factual.opener: Everyone's got rumors, Lenart. What actually changed out there?
variants: Quiet, but not by choice. City feels locked down tighter every day.
Whole network's out of tune. Folks can't even get their own files back.
Saw more agents around, making sure no one gets clever.
Heard something about IDs not matching, but can't say more.
More patrols. Council's holding all the cards now, not sharing anything useful.
People with the wrong numbers are stuck or missing.
Labor assignments make no sense - whoever's in charge isn't in control.
Free zones are where folks are coping best, but that's drawing attention.
Plenty disappear without a word lately.
City's jumbled up since Halden went down. The Council says order, but no one's buying it.
Saw folks with high scores sweeping floors while the flagged man the terminals - just chaos.
Council's busy selling this Unified Charter, but most only follow it with a watcher nearby.
Free zones organize their own shifts, don't care about the registry. System can't keep up.
A lot more people use analog tricks now. Quiet resistance - happens everywhere.
Heard the Directorate's trying to silence things, shutting down comms. Makes you rely on who you know.
I keep out of the crossfire, but I know which side I'd stand on.
It's gotten strange. Used to run on routine, now every day's adjusted by rumor and workaround.
Council trying to push this new Charter, but most free zones won't touch it. Saw councils fake compliance just to keep the heat off.
Labor got scrambled - used to be menial jobs for us low-score types, now you'll see a Council favorite scrubbing floors and vice versa. Whole thing's laughable if it wasn't dangerous.
Friends in free zones swap roles, share food, ignore BCI. Feels more human than official channels ever did.
A few of us move info with nothing digital. Handwritten, face-to-face, you name it.
Council's pressuring people to turn each other in, but most refuse. Too much bad blood after what happened to Halden.
Lost track of how many times folks have renounced the system publicly. Doesn't stop the agents, but the mood's changed.
If you ask me, people running their own lives beats any algorithm the Council's peddling.
Tired as hell. The city's theater - acting like the Council's in charge, but it's all smoke.
When Halden died, whatever order there was died with him. BCI started eating itself - neighbors swapped jobs, nothing lined up, whole districts got paralyzed.
Council threw out that 'Unified Civic Charter' like it meant anything. Locals stage their own mock registrations, just to buy time. We laugh about it later - if we're lucky not to get flagged.

Saw folks I trust start underground signal lines. Passed old data chips with alternate city plans. Crazy thing is, some people believe those visions could actually happen - even the councilors are scared.
Labor tools rerouted me once - got an assignment in a data center I'd helped sabotage before. They clearly have no idea who belongs where anymore.
I meet friends after curfew, pass paper lists, mark the buildings the Directorate still can't crack because of old rewirings I put in.
Renunciation's a festival now - you see BCI tokens smashed, Council posters torn down, old neighbors offering dinner instead of suspicion. Binds folks tighter than anything the system built.
Used to fix things just to get by. Now it's sidelong warnings, teaching kids to organize, making sure the busiest places run without a single byte of Council code.
Say what you will, but I'll take risky freedom over their idea of order any day. Could be trouble, but at least it's ours.

questions.neutral: Night's only just started, hasn't it?

hobby.message: Still folding origami to stay grounded?
Any luck fixing the old typewriter?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Night runs long lately. I pass time with old machines, typewriters mostly.
Mechanical hobbies keep hands busy when the city's in uproar.
Power cuts lately, can't always use them. I write less these days.
People notice what you do, even when it's harmless.
Not much left to do after curfew, so I keep to my typewriters.
Restoring those old keys keeps me occupied.
Blackouts make it hard - ribbons and parts harder to find.
Some don't like records being kept, even personal ones.
You learn what to write, what not to.
I spend evenings restoring antique typewriters, mechanical ones from before everything got digitized.
I keep a handwritten journal too, habit from before the BCI scored everything.
It's quieter since the Charter - no one wants anything in writing now.
Power outages make repairs tricky. Last week, lost a half-finished letter to darkness.
The community used to swap parts, now everyone keeps to themselves.
Feels strange to tap keys in silence while the city discards their tokens.
I collect and restore vintage typewriters - Olympias, Royals, whatever still has a voice.
My journal fills up faster since those blackout days began.
Writing by hand feels like a small rebellion now, doesn't it?
People threw their BCI tokens away, but some of us hold onto old stories.
Supply lines are unpredictable - finding typewriter ribbon is nearly impossible since the Charter.
Hard to know who notices, but I keep all my best work on paper.
Sometimes, I think the machine remembers more than we do.
You know, I used to manage Council schedules on an Olympia SM9. Kept one for myself.
Restoring typewriters is a lifeline now. I write about things we aren't meant to remember.
Blackouts force me onto paper - no digital footprints, that's safety now.
After the Charter mess, I saw neighbors burning journals. I hide mine in locked drawers.
Parts are a barter currency among the old registry staff. Some are quietly keeping history alive.
The Directorate doesn't trust written records, not outside official channels.
My BCI score dropped after I refused to hand over some personal logs.
Most people forget, but keys and paper outlast the system. Always have.
hobby_answer: Yes, just routine maintenance on the old one.
Spare ribbons are hard to get these days.
Everything's becoming difficult. Even harmless hobbies.
Can't be too careful now.
People pay attention to the wrong things lately.
Yes, an Olympia - thought I'd keep it running.
Can't rely on the grid for much, so typewriters help.
Harder with the power down - felt like someone was watching.
Saw a few neighbors get too curious about my workshop.
Work best behind closed curtains lately.
You noticed - yes, an SM9 from the seventies. Reliable, unlike the BCI.
Spent an afternoon cataloguing old notes during the communications blackout.
Strange feeling - typing suddenly sounds too loud with everything silent outside.
Lost my last new ribbon during this week's unrest. Even paper feels risky.
Neighbors outside tossing BCI tokens - makes you reflect how fragile things get.
My hobby was a refuge, now it attracts stares.
I keep the curtains drawn.
Right - you've got a good eye, SM9 again.
Spent most of the blackout sorting notes by candlelight.
Used to trade ribbons at flea markets, but those are closed now.
Two hours into typing, power cuts, neighbors protesting BCI tokens outside.
Felt each keystroke was being tracked - paranoia or just habit?
Running low on supplies - odd what's become valuable.
Old hobbies draw suspicion - strange times.
Sometimes a pencil and envelope feel safer than a typewriter.
You remember the SM9. Came from a Council office clearance after Halden passed.
Typewriters remind me of quiet order. Now, even that's been compromised.
Last Tuesday, I started cataloguing notes but the blackout hit mid-task.
Neighbors burned their BCI tokens - chaos outside, keys too loud inside.
I've run out of new ribbons, probably for good now.
To think, I helped design some of these protocols. Now they watch everyone, even me.
People used to respect paper records - now they're dangerous.
I keep everything in coded envelopes, sometimes use old Directorate ciphers.
It's odd wishing for the days when hobbies were just hobbies.

main.opener: You notice people acting different lately?
variants: People always notice something. Stenograd is never still.
I just follow procedure. Helped keep some files in order, that's all.
Not everyone likes the paperwork these days.
Makes you less welcome in your own hallway, to be honest.
I helped coordinate the record transfers for the Council. Quiet work, but necessary.
Some neighbors took issue with it. There were words. Flyers on my door.
Regulations keep changing. I followed protocol, nothing more.
Most people don't like protocols. They want answers, or someone to blame.
Feels like there's not much room for quiet anymore.
After Halden died, someone had to manage the truth records. I advised moving everything under Council lock.
Neighborhood leaders wanted access. I couldn't allow it; too many risks.
Old colleagues asked for exceptions. I said no, for everyone's safety.
Now the archives are locked up. It's not making anyone happy.
Neighbors avoid me. I'm the reason assemblies stopped.
That's life. You do what's needed, then pay for it.
I spent years keeping Council business quiet. After Halden's death, it seemed right to centralize all records.
I coordinated with Directorate teams. Blocked the neighborhood assemblies myself.
Some old acquaintances tried to pressure me. I explained: you can't just open up the archives in times like this.
Within days, people were putting my name on protest flyers.
Now, no one speaks to me. Even my BCI score dropped - lower than most dissidents.
It's strange. You serve by following orders, and still, you lose everything else.
Guess that's the price for loyalty now.
You know, I spent more than a decade as assistant to the Council. Most days, it was calendars and protocols, but I've seen how quick the crowd turns.

After Halden's death, chaos moved in. I was the one who said: lock down the truth records, consolidate everything. It made sense from a Directorate's view - otherwise, information spirals out of control.
I even drafted the new security regs myself. Sent Directorate agents to verify every file move. People confronted me at my own door, shouting about freedoms and assemblies.
Didn't matter. The Council followed my advice and suspended all truth assemblies.
Soon, everyone started rejecting the Council itself - renouncing tokens, ignoring the system. Doesn't look much like order now.
Neighbors avoid me. Some say I'm the cause; I can't argue. Losing the city's trust, getting isolated... it's a lonely thing.
Strange to hold the line for order, only to lose your place in it.
If it had gone any other way, someone else would be the outcast. That's the risk you take for believing in structure.
main.emotion: Tired, quietly isolated, resigned to public backlash but uncertain what comes next.

emotional.opener: Nikola, no one else could have held things together as long as you did. Most would have broken under that weight. I hope you know you did what you thought was necessary.
variants: It wasn't easy. I suppose most things aren't anymore.
Thank you. You see the cracks people miss. That means something.
Sometimes you do what's needed, not what you want.
Your words are...unexpected. They help more than I'll admit.
I did what anyone in my position would have, or so I tell myself.
You learn to live with regret. Never to like it.
Routine is a comfort when nothing else is.
No one prepares you for the aftermath. I suppose you understand that better than most.
Yes, I did what I thought was necessary. It still sits heavy, regardless.
People talk about legacy, but most of us just leave paperwork.
Some nights I wonder if I could have acted differently. Most nights, I don't sleep.
It means something that you bothered to say this.
You remind me of those rare few who saw past the surface, even now.
The quiet after everything is worse than the storm, you know.
My loyalty was always to the system - clean lines, clear rules. Emotions were off the ledger.
Sometimes I wonder if anyone could have held it together longer. Sometimes I know the answer.
Guilt and pride, both stubborn houseguests. I keep them in separate rooms.
I haven't felt understood in a long time, so...thank you.

factual.opener: Everyone knows the city's in pieces, Nikola. So what really happened after Halden?
variants: Some disruptions after Halden's death. Systems stopped running as expected.
People started swapping jobs, labor tools were confused.
Council said little, but ordered tighter controls.
That's all I can say.
Labor placements got scrambled. Wrong people in wrong jobs everywhere.
Council factions blamed each other, nothing settled.
They shut down digital channels to quiet things. Turned people inventive, not quiet.
Then came forced Charter registration. Protests followed.
I kept out of the rest.
After Halden, malfunctions everywhere - labor, assignments, even basic services misfired.
Council lines hardened. Directorate pushed for strict lockdown, Harmonists stalled, Innovators just blamed the old code.
They cut digital comms. Neighbors built their own message trails, quietly passed around banned recordings.
People formed those 'free zones' - assigning work themselves, skipping BCI scores.
Council rushed out the Civic Charter, tried pushing everyone back into line with old credentials.
That only deepened the schism. Protests, mass token disposal, visible rejection.
Between us: strict order rarely survives empty streets.
Halden's end broke the system's spine. Random assignments made a joke of expertise and trust.
Directorate got nervous. Council went for total shutdown on comms. People hid messages in analog, paper, old radio bands - anything to stay connected.
A rival data chip appeared, showing a different future. It made the free zones bold, gave people hope for another kind of order.
Council tried ramming through the Civic Charter, Directorate officers enforcing old BCI logs. No one respected it.
Assemblies broadcast evidence of Council lies, people gathered for peaceful defiance - no violence, just silence and mass refusals.
My own work kept me looped into how desperate the Directorate became when control slipped. The Harmonists panicked, Innovators vanished.
People discarded their tokens. That was it - the moment the system lost the street.
Order means nothing if no one's willing to believe in it.
When Halden went, chaos crept in. Labor reassignments went haywire, compliance tools malfunctioned, all trust in the hierarchy vanished overnight.
Directorate feared open revolt. They demanded digital silence, so citizens built a network using smuggled analog gear. I heard some of the tapes - people weren't afraid, just done obeying.
Then a simulation chip appeared - meant to stay secret, but leaked anyway. It showed an alternative Stenograd, which made the Council frantic. Directorate tried to suppress, but failed.
Free zones became real governance, ignoring BCI scores. I sat in on secret Council calls where they admitted we'd lost the people, but still hoped procedures would fix it.
The Civic Charter was a last gamble - forcing zones back into the registry. It failed. Protesters exposed that the Council faked support, assemblies unified against BCI enforcement.
I'd drafted regs like those myself for years. Never saw them ignored so completely. Even Directorate agents wavered, some quietly quit.
Most citizens renounced their tokens, a public show of rejection.
Now, no one feels loyal to the old system. The city belongs to its people again, but no one's sure if that's chaos or a new order.
It was always easier trusting chain of command. Now, routine is just another rumor.

hobby.message: Origami help keep the noise out?
Freestyle FPV... your kind of silence, right?
You bring something banned books with you again?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Still breathing. Just keeping to myself.
I fold origami, keeps my mind focused.
Been harder lately with everyone on edge.
Paper's harder to find after those Charter broadcasts.
Breathing. As much as anyone can now.
I do origami - mostly with old bills or scrap paper.
Makes the hours pass.
Feels riskier now, especially after the BCI drama.
Had to fold less since the protests started.
Still standing, I suppose. The city feels... changed.
I fold complex origami models to settle my thoughts.
It's small paper - utility forms make good swans.
Last week, I folded on my balcony and watched people discard tokens.
It used to be peaceful, but lately, even that feels noticed.
Sometimes, you sense eyes every time you crease a corner.
Breathing, sure, but Stenograd's... different. Hard to ignore it now.
Origami's kept me grounded through most changes - pelicans, tessellations, modular stars.
I collect castoff forms before they shred them now; paper's precious.
After the Civic Charter, neighbors burn tokens below my balcony while I fold.
Feels like even folding isn't private anymore - someone is always watching.
But it's what I have. I keep scraps hidden just to keep at it.
Funny, how the hobby's gone from harmless to feeling almost risky.
Still breathing - barely, sometimes. Everything feels exposed these days.
My escape is origami. I've built hundreds - cranes, insects, fractals - since I joined the Directorate.
I love the folding math. It feels orderly - even as the world falls apart.
Now, even that's changed. I used to fold quietly after work; lately the protests echo through the block.
When people started tearing up Council forms, I nearly stopped folding myself.
I keep a stash of old tokens and forms, just for folding. It feels defiant.
Sometimes I wonder if someone tracks the patterns I make. Paranoid, maybe, but hard to shake.
Still, when the city's this unstable, a well-creased paper swan is the only thing that makes sense.
hobby_answer: Just a simple model today. Nothing special.
Used scrap paper from the Directorate.
Hard to focus with all the Charter noise lately.
Not many chances to fold safely now.
That's all, really.
Yeah, one in my coat pocket. Nothing fancy.
These days, folding at home only.
Council broadcasts make the walls feel thinner.
Saw some neighbors burning old BCI forms. Makes you think.
Can't relax into it like before. Too visible.
I keep routines small, just in case.
I did, actually - a modular fold from old notices.
Origami used to feel private, almost meditative for me.
Ever since the Charter launch, everything feels exposed.
Neighbors gather, tear up tokens. Folding by the window feels risky.
Carrying models outside draws glances now. Suspicion everywhere.
Odd, but even a paper crane can feel like defiance.
I never thought I'd worry over a hobby.
Yes, in my pocket. Little swan, folded from Civic Charter mail.
Origami gives my mind structure when things spiral.
Now, even old hobbies get political. I'm careful where I unfold anything.
Charter broadcasts, BCI checks outside - privacy feels gone.
I used to share models, but now I keep them hidden.
Neighbors burning tokens, meetings on the stairs - all visible from my terrace.
I hear people judging anything that looks like Directorate approval.
Each fold feels complicated now, but I still do it.
Always. Today it's a tessellation, made from last week's Council reminder sheet.
Folding's my way to process things - order in small steps.
Growing up, it was just a quiet skill. Lately, it's something else.
Everyone outside discards BCI tokens, but I still keep my hands busy.
After the Charter, carrying even a paper model marks you as suspicious or a loyalist.
I had a neighbor glare when I folded on the stairs. Used to ask for lessons.
The broadcasts sound like threats now. Sometimes I turn the radio up to drown them out.
There's comfort in folding, even if people watch from afar.
Feels like holding onto a piece of myself as the city changes.

main.opener: Hard to keep track of what's normal anymore. What's that look like for you?
variants: Hard to say what normal is now. They changed my building access last week.
I'm only called to work if I'm needed, so mostly I wait.
Some doors just stay closed, even when you knock.
I just feel... cut off. Like I'm outside looking in, and I don't know how to get back.
These days, normal means getting stopped by your own building scanners.
I don't really see anyone at the Directorate unless they summon me.
Tried to help someone with their files, but got blocked from the archive.
My score keeps dropping. The committee won't even talk to me now.
I just feel... cut off. Like I'm outside looking in, and I don't know how to get back.
I guess it used to mean routine. Now, it's showing up at work and finding out my clearance is gone.
They only call me if something urgent happens.
I walked around the district and saw people just taking off their BCI tokens - like the rules don't apply anymore.
I tried to help a flagged resident get their archive. Couldn't.
Even the resident committee pushes me away now, like I'm not on anyone's side.
I just feel... cut off. Like I'm outside looking in, and I don't know how to get back.
Normal? I used to think it was helping the city run smoothly, catching patterns in the system.
When my access was downgraded, even getting into my office felt wrong.
Walking outside, you see entire blocs ignoring BCI, meeting in public and sharing things without logging it.
I tried to retrieve records for someone who needed help, but I've lost that kind of access now - no one trusts me, neither the Directorate nor the neighbors.
Spent an afternoon just sorting my files, waiting to see what else they'd take from me.
I stopped joining local meetings. Too visible, too risky.
My BCI score keeps dropping. It's... easier to just disappear.
I just feel... cut off. Like I'm outside looking in, and I don't know how to get back.
Normal means something different to me every month. At first, I believed the BCI was keeping everything balanced, keeping people safe.
But after watching someone lose their apartment over a minor mistake, I started questioning why I worked there.
Now, banned from most places - not for something I did, but just because of the Directorate association.
I used to believe the Harmonists had the right idea. Control, but humane. Not silent exile like this.
Saw people outside today, taking off their BCI tokens and ignoring the rules - almost celebrating their disobedience.
Tried to help someone with their old case files, but access is locked. Even my neighbors refuse my help - they see me as part of the machine.
I spend more time alone sorting my life, waiting for the next thing to fall away. No meetings, no invitations. Losing connections, piece by piece.
I just feel... cut off. Like I'm outside looking in, and I don't know how to get back.
main.emotion: I just feel... cut off. Like I'm outside looking in, and I don't know how to get back.

emotional.opener: You know, feeling cut off doesn't mean you're broken. Sometimes it's the world that changed, not you.
variants: Maybe. Things just shifted, I guess.
Hard to say what normal is anymore.
Yeah. I try to remind myself it's not just me.
Maybe it's safer to step back a bit.
Easier to watch than to get pulled in sometimes.
You're right. It's not always my fault if things feel distant.
I keep thinking everyone else is inside something I can't reach.
Sometimes it's... quieter out here, at least.
I guess I'll get used to it.
It helps to hear that. I keep second-guessing myself.
Feels like the rules keep changing and I can't keep up.
People I knew, they don't even look at me the same anymore.
I keep wondering if I missed a sign, or did something wrong.
But maybe it isn't just me after all.
Maybe the fault isn't mine. That's new to admit.
I used to think keeping to the system would protect me, make connections simple.
Now I see how easily everything flips, how fast distance grows.
It's strange, feeling invisible in a city that never stops watching.
But when you say it like that, it sounds survivable. Like it's not a personal failure.
Thanks for giving me another way to see it.

factual.opener: You keep saying you're on the outside, but that's what everyone says. What exactly happened? What's really going on out there?
variants: Most people just talk about how nothing works right now.
Seen some leaving their tokens. That's it.
Council keeps sending announcements. Not many listen.
Hard to know what's real when everything changes every day.
People stick to their own streets. Can't blame them.
Neighborhood groups are saying the Council's lost control.
Heard the Directorate tried to take over the archives, shut down the assemblies.
Communications feel monitored or just dead.
Some folks openly ignore the BCI now, nobody stops them.
They talk about a new Charter, but not many trust it.
I don't know if any of that matters anymore.
The Council ordered truth assemblies to give up their records. Said it was for stability.
Then came the Civic Charter. Felt like it was supposed to force everyone back in line.
Free zones - they're organizing without BCI. You see people sorting work and supplies themselves.
Nobody's listening to the compliance lists. The enforcement... it's just noise now.
Some show evidence the Charter wasn't even agreed on. Publicly, it's a mess.
Nonviolent protests all over. The system's losing its grip.
If you'd told me last year we'd see this, I wouldn't have believed it.
Truth archives are locked down by order. No one gets access but the Directorate.
Saw memos - central registry's a forced move. Free councils never gave real consent.
I've watched whole streets toss out their tokens. Feels final.
People stage protests in daylight now, refusing even basic BCI ID checks.
The Harmonist idea - balance, decency - even that feels impossible. Too many lines crossed.
Colleagues admit the Charter's barely enforceable. Nothing's holding together.
I'm not sure what side I'm on anymore. That... worries me more than being cut off.
No one's giving orders, but everyone's taking a stand.
The archives - for truth assemblies, neighborhood records - are sealed. Directorate controls every request. Even old cases are impossible to help with now.
Council directives feel like desperation. The Civic Charter's just a screen - most councils went around it, and now central authority's basically collapsed.
Saw logs: BCI labor tools are broken, jobs shuffled, chaos everywhere. High-scorers idle, low-scored people assigned to critical work. A joke, except it hurts real people.
Meetings I'm not welcome at anymore, because former colleagues blame me for things no one could control.
I stayed with Harmonists because I believed we kept things ethical, but it's clear the system's running on inertia - no control, no decency.
Free zones ignore central orders and redistribute resources. Some actually work better this way.
Public renunciation of tokens is everywhere, real risk of violence if anyone tries to enforce Council rules.
Privately, I think we've passed the point of repair. Most here won't admit it, but without Halden, we're just improvising. Even those in charge know it.
Feels like the city's re-learning to exist without models or metrics - something raw and unfinished.
